verses.text: Whoever separates himself seeks his own desire; he breaks out against all sound judgment.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the dangers of isolating oneself from the wisdom that comes from community, an implicit reference to the communal nature of the Church described in Acts 2:42.

verses.text: A fool takes no pleasure in understanding, but only in expressing his own opinion.
verses.comment: The contrast between knowledge and self-will echoes James 1:19, emphasizing humility before God’s truth.

verses.text: When wickedness comes, contempt comes with it, and with dishonor comes disgrace.
verses.comment: Moral failure brings dishonor in both the visible and spiritual communities, reflecting Romans 6:21.

verses.text: The words of a man’s mouth are deep waters; the fountain of wisdom is a bubbling brook.
verses.comment: The 'fountain of wisdom' points to the living water described in John 7:38—a spiritual reading connecting wisdom to Christ.

verses.text: It is not good to show partiality to the wicked, or to deprive the righteous of justice.
verses.comment: True justice is a reflection of God's character and order, and is vital for the unity of God’s people.

verses.text: A fool’s lips walk into a fight, and his mouth invites a beating.
verses.comment: Words have consequences, and this recalls Jesus’ teachings on speech and judgment in Matthew 12:36.

verses.text: A fool’s mouth is his ruin, and his lips are a snare to his soul.
verses.comment: Speech not only affects others but can endanger one’s soul—see James 3:6.

verses.text: The words of a gossip are like delicious morsels; they go down into the inner parts of the body.
verses.comment: The impact of rumor can affect a person deeply—showing the grave spiritual consequences of careless speaking.

verses.text: Whoever is slack in his work is brother to him who destroys.
verses.comment: Neglect of duty is equated with destruction—reminding us that faithfulness in deeds matters, not just words.

verses.text: The name of the LORD is a strong tower; the righteous run to it and are safe.
verses.comment: The 'name' signifies God’s very presence and authority—a precursor to the invocation of God's name as protection found in Acts 4:12.

verses.text: A rich person’s wealth is his strong city, and like a high wall in his imagination.
verses.comment: Contrast between trusting in God (v.10) and trusting in riches, as Jesus warns about wealth in Mark 10:24.

verses.text: Before destruction a man’s heart is proud, but humility comes before honor.
verses.comment: True honor comes through humility, foreshadowing the humility of Christ (Philippians 2:8–9).

verses.text: If one gives an answer before he hears, it is his folly and shame.
verses.comment: Listening is elevated as a virtue, closely tied with the biblical call to obedience.

verses.text: The spirit of a man will sustain him in sickness, but a crushed spirit who can bear?
verses.comment: Spiritual strength is vital, reminiscent of Paul’s exhortation in 2 Corinthians 4:16.

verses.text: An intelligent heart acquires knowledge, and the ear of the wise seeks knowledge.
verses.comment: The pursuit of wisdom is central to the faith and aligns with the scriptural pattern of seeking deeper truth (Matthew 7:7).

verses.text: A man’s gift makes room for him and brings him before great people.
verses.comment: Generosity and appropriate gifting opens doors—even to those in authority.

verses.text: The one who states his case first seems right, until another comes and examines him.
verses.comment: Truth is established by careful discernment and examination, reflecting the scriptural pattern for judgment in the Church.

verses.text: Casting the lot puts an end to quarrels and decides between the mighty.
verses.comment: The use of lots acknowledges God's sovereignty in decisions—see also Proverbs 16:33 and the selection of Matthias in Acts.

verses.text: A brother offended is more unyielding than a strong city, and disputes are like the bars of a fortress.
verses.comment: The importance of reconciliation is central, foreshadowing Jesus’ call to unity (John 17:21).

verses.text: From the fruit of a man’s mouth his stomach is filled; with the harvest of his lips he is satisfied.
verses.comment: Words produce outcomes, just as faith put into action produces spiritual fruit—see Galatians 5:22.

verses.text: Death and life are in the power of the tongue, and those who love it will eat its fruit.
verses.comment: The tongue’s spiritual power recalls the importance of confession, both of sin and faith, as an ongoing practice (Romans 10:10; 1 John 1:9).

verses.text: He who finds a wife finds a good thing and obtains favor from the LORD.
verses.comment: Marriage is described as a gift from God, implying it is a vocation and mirrors the relationship of Christ and the Church (Ephesians 5:31–32).

verses.text: The poor man pleads for mercy, but the rich man answers harshly.
verses.comment: Scripture warns against pride and injustice towards the poor, calling for compassion as a mark of true faith.

verses.text: A man of many companions may come to ruin, but there is a friend who sticks closer than a brother.
verses.comment: True friendship is rooted in sacrificial, faithful love—ultimately fulfilled in Christ who laid down his life for his friends.
